text: Evoked Potentials are deflection of the EEG signal following the presentation of a sensory input.
explanation: TRUE

text: Movements of the subject's head produces artifacts only in the gamma band.
explanation: Movement of the subject's head may produce slow artifacts on the EEG recording, whose waveform is closely related to the timecourse of the movement

text: Event-Related Desynchronization/ Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify the amount of coupling between signals on two EEG channels.
explanation: ERD/S quantify changes of the power of EEG relative to a baseline period

text: Event-Related Desynchronization/Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify phase-locked brain activity in response to an event
explanation: Event-Related Desynchronization/Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify relative changes of the power of the EEG rhythm in a predefined frequency range; phase locked activity is estimated using the synchronized averaging.

text: In an ADC, quantization introduces a noise whose amplitude is proportional to the width of the quantization interval (VLSB): σquant = 1/√12 VLSB
explanation: TRUE

text: The powerline noise affects a very narrow frequency band of the recorded signal around 50 Hz (in Europe) and odd multiples of (150 Hz, 250 Hz, ...).
explanation: TRUE

text: The frequency spectrum of white noise is flat, i.e. it has the same power at any frequency.
explanation: TRUE

text: A FIR filter needs to be of a higher order to achieve the same quality specifications than a IIR filter.
explanation: TRUE

text: The contact impedances of a pair of electrodes should be large compared to the input impedance of the differential amplifier connected to them, otherwise the amplitude of the signal would be reduced as effect of the potential divider.
explanation: False, the contact impedances must be lower than the amplifier's input impedance, mainly to help keeping the circuit balanced (higher CMRR)

text: Aliasing occurs when an artifact corrupts an otherwise healthy EEG recording.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when the sampling frequency of an analog signal is lower than twice the frequency of any spectral component of the signal

text: The CMRR of a bipolar amplifier measures how much higher is the gain of the potential difference between the input electrodes with respect to the gain of their average with respect to the electrical ground.
explanation: TRUE

text: A 'run' is a portion of recording in an experimental protocol that contains no breaks, i.e. all samples contained therein have been acquired 1/fs seconds after the previous (fs being the sampling frequency)
explanation: TRUE

text: EEG signals recorded in monopolar configuration can be re-referenced to the Common Average Reference (CAR), by subtracting from each channel the instantaneous average of all channels. In ideal conditions, this would approximate taking the reference potential at infinity.
explanation: TRUE

text: The Shannon's theorem states that a continuous signal can be properly sampled only if it does not contain frequency components above the sampling rate.
explanation: The signal must not contain spectral components above half the sampling rate (Nyquist frequency)

text: The N20 component of an EP occurs before the stimulus (negative latency) while the P300 occurs after the stimulus (positive latency).
explanation: 'N' and 'P' indicate the sign of the amplitude of the ERP (Negative and Positive, respectively), not the latency.

text: The RMS and the ARV of a zero-mean signal have the same value (assume that the number of samples N → ∞).
explanation: For a zero-mean signal, the RMS equals the standard deviation σ of a zero-mean signal.

text: In ERP analysis, ‘trials' are portions of the continuous EEG recording that start exactly at the time when a sensory stimulus was delivered
explanation: The start of a trial usually precedes the time of the event, so that a pre-stimulus baseline period can be analyzed. Events are not necessarily sensory stimulations.

text: The mu rhythm and the alpha rhythm are EEG components that differ for their fundamental frequency of oscillation
explanation: They both oscillate around 10 Hz.

text: ARVx = √(1/N) Σ(x[i])², where the sum extends on the N samples of the signal x[i]
explanation: ARVx = (1/N) Σ|x[i]|, ARV being the acronym of Average Rectified Value

text: In a P300-based BCI, the user subjectively assigns saliency (relevance) to a stimulus so that their brain produces a P300 ERP every time the stimulus is administered
explanation: TRUE

text: An EEG recording is said to be bipolar when it comprises exactly two channels
explanation: In bipolar EEG recordings, each channel is the difference of potential between two (adjacent) electrodes. The number of channels is not relevant

text: The roll-off of a filter is the slope of its frequency response in the transition band. It is high when the transition band is narrow.
explanation: TRUE

text: The Short Time Fourier Transform (STFT) is a simple method to estimate a spectrogram, i.e. the representation of the time-varying spectrum of a non-stationary signal.
explanation: TRUE

text: The amplitude of an ERP is measured with respect to its value at the time of the event.
explanation: The amplitude of ERPs is measured with respect to a baseline epoch (usually preceding the stimulus), in which the amplitude is assumed to be zero.

text: The alpha rhythm can be observed by filtering the spontaneous EEG signal using a narrowband filter, with cutoff frequencies at 14 and 30 Hz (approximately)
explanation: With these cutoff frequencies we would observe the beta rhythm

text: The heart activity is likely to contaminate an EEG recording if the reference electrode is not placed on the head.
explanation: TRUE

text: Evoked potential is synonymous of Event-Related Potentials
explanation: Event related potentials include evoke potentials, as well as EEG responses to motor or cognitive events.

text: In an ERP, the response to a stimulus has a reduced amplitude when the SOA is too short.
explanation: TRUE

text: In an ADC, quantization introduces a noise whose amplitude is proportional to the number L of discrete amplitude levels: σquant = 1/L = 1/√12 VLSB
explanation: The quantization noise amplitude is proportional to the width of the quantization interval (VLSB): σquant = 1/√12 VLSB

text: The artifact generated by eye movements can reach amplitudes up to 5µV in the EEG recordings
explanation: EOG artifacts can be two orders of magnitude higher than that.

text: The synchronized average of N trials containing only spontaneous EEG whose variance {var}{trial}=σ^2 is a signal whose variance {var}{avg}=σ^2/N
explanation: TRUE

text: The frequency response of a filter in the stopband should be plotted in a graph whose vertical axis has a logarithmic scale (i.e. the gain is expressed in dB).
explanation: TRUE

text: The CMRR of a bipolar amplifier measures the ratio between the gain of their average with respect to the electrical ground and the gain of the potential difference between the input electrodes.
explanation: Numerator and denominator are swapped

text: Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled using a limited input range of the ADC.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled outside the conditions set by the Shannon's theorem. Clipping (saturation) occurs when the input range of the ADC is smaller than the amplitude of the input analog signal.

text: Despite being more expensive, gold electrodes should be preferred to Ag/AgCl electrodes since they allow recording of extremely slow-changing EEG potentials.
explanation: Gold electrodes are polarizable, thus the opposite is true

text: EEG electrodes whose first letter of the label is "C" (e.g. "Cz") are located on the central region of the head, i.e. the region between the left and the right hemisphere
explanation: The central region is above the central sulcus which divides the frontal and parietal lobes. The mesial region is above the interhemispheric scissure, and it is designated by a trailing "z" in EEG labels

text: The measurement of two monopolar EEG channels requires four electrodes – two collecting the potentials fed to the non-inverting input of the differential amplifier, one providing the reference potential and one providing the ground potential.
explanation: TRUE

text: In analog-to-digital conversion, each spectral component of the analog signal should have frequency below the Nyquist frequency
explanation: TRUE

text: In ERP analysis, the EEG continuous recording must be segmented into epochs (trials) of fixed duration, each aligned to a repetition of the event
explanation: TRUE

text: The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) states that the average of N zero-mean independent identically distributed signals approaches zero for N → ∞.
explanation: TRUE

text: As a preliminary step to EEG data analysis, one or more channels can be removed from the dataset if they are extensively contaminated by artifacts
explanation: TRUE

text: The proper (visual) alpha rhythm is modulated (synchronized, desynchronized) by opening and closing the eyes. This phenomenon is best observed on the frontal EEG channels.
explanation: Only the first half of the statement is true. The primary visual area is located in the occipital cortex, thus the occipital (and parietal) channels are most sensitive.

text: Given two ranges of equal width A=[-0.1,+0.1] and B=[0.8,1.0], it is less likely that samples of a sinewave x=(t) will have amplitude in A rather than B.
explanation: TRUE, the probability density function of amplitude is lowest for x = 0

text: A BCI system may replace functions that are physiologically subserved by nerves and muscles, by directly measuring brain activity and converting it to an artificial output.
explanation: TRUE

text: The advantage of a high CMRR amplifier is that it suppresses high frequency disturbance.
explanation: The advantage of a high CMRR amplifier is that it suppresses common-mode disturbances, such as powerline (50 Hz) noise.

text: The purpose a filter is to allow desired spectral component of a signal to pass almost unaltered, while attenuating undesired spectral components
explanation: TRUE

text: The DFT of a signal represents the amplitude Ai and initial phases φi of sinewave components of the signal at frequencies fi ranging from 0Hz (included) to the sampling frequency (excluded).
explanation: TRUE

text: The Inter-Stimulus Interval (ISI) equals the SOA minus the ITI.
explanation: The ISI equals the SOA minus the stimulus duration.

text: The purpose a filter is to allow desired spectral component of a signal to pass almost unaltered, while attenuating undesired spectral components
explanation: TRUE

text: The DFT of a signal represents the amplitude Ai and initial phases φi of sinewave components of the signal at frequencies fi ranging from 0Hz (included) to the sampling frequency (excluded).
explanation: TRUE

text: In ERP analysis, the EEG continuous recording must be segmented into epochs (trials) of fixed duration, each aligned to a repetition of the event
explanation: TRUE

text: A negative peak in a ERP recorded on a specific subject with a latency of 108ms may still be named N100, if it matches the physiological phenomenon of the nominal N100 component.
explanation: TRUE

text: In an ERP, the response to a stimulus has a reduced amplitude when the SOA is too short.
explanation: TRUE

text: Despite being more expensive, gold electrodes should be preferred to Ag/AgCl electrodes since they allow recording of extremely slow-changing EEG potentials.
explanation: Gold electrodes are polarizable, thus the opposite is true

text: EEG electrodes whose first letter of the label is "C" (e.g. "Cz") are located on the central region of the head, i.e. the region between the left and the right hemisphere
explanation: The central region is above the central sulcus which divides the frontal and parietal lobes. The mesial region is above the interhemispheric scissure, and it is designated by a trailing "z" in EEG labels

text: Ensuring a contact impedance below 5 kΩ is not relevant when the input impedance of the EEG amplifier is below 50 kΩ
explanation: The opposite is true: the input impedance of the EEG amplifier must be several orders of magnitude higher than the contact impedance

text: The artifact generated by eye movements can reach amplitudes up to 5µV in the EEG recordings
explanation: EOG artifacts can be two orders of magnitude higher than that.

text: The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) states that the average of N zero-mean independent identically distributed signals approaches zero for N → ∞.
explanation: TRUE

text: The measurement of two monopolar EEG channels requires four electrodes – two collecting the potentials fed to the non-inverting input of the differential amplifier, one providing the reference potential and one providing the ground potential.
explanation: TRUE

text: In analog-to-digital conversion, each spectral component of the analog signal should have frequency below the Nyquist frequency
explanation: TRUE

text: The heart activity is likely to contaminate an EEG recording if the reference electrode is not placed on the head.
explanation: TRUE

text: The alpha rhythm can be observed by filtering the spontaneous EEG signal using a narrowband filter, with cutoff frequencies at 14 and 30 Hz (approximately)
explanation: With these cutoff frequencies we would observe the beta rhythm

text: The synchronized average of N trials containing only spontaneous EEG whose variance {var}{trial}=σ^2 is a signal whose variance {var}{avg}=σ^2/N
explanation: TRUE

text: The proper (visual) alpha rhythm is modulated (synchronized, desynchronized) by opening and closing the eyes. This phenomenon is best observed on the frontal EEG channels.
explanation: Only the first half of the statement is true. The primary visual area is located in the occipital cortex, thus the occipital (and parietal) channels are most sensitive.

text: In an ADC, quantization introduces a noise whose amplitude is proportional to the width of the quantization interval (VLSB): σquant = 1/√12 VLSB
explanation: TRUE

text: As a preliminary step to EEG data analysis, one or more channels can be removed from the dataset if they are extensively contaminated by artifacts
explanation: TRUE

text: A BCI system may replace functions that are physiologically subserved by nerves and muscles, by directly measuring brain activity and converting it to an artificial output.
explanation: TRUE

text: The CMRR of a bipolar amplifier measures the ratio between the gain of their average with respect to the electrical ground and the gain of the potential difference between the input electrodes.
explanation: Numerator and denominator are swapped

text: The frequency response of a filter in the stopband should be plotted in a graph whose vertical axis has a logarithmic scale (i.e. the gain is expressed in dB).
explanation: TRUE

text: Evoked potential is synonymous of Event-Related Potentials
explanation: Event related potentials include evoke potentials, as well as EEG responses to motor or cognitive events.

text: The RMS is the square root of the average of the squared value of the samples of a signal
Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled using a limited input range of the ADC.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled outside the conditions set by the Shannon's theorem. Clipping (saturation) occurs when the input range of the ADC is smaller than the amplitude of the input analog signal.

text: We need to measure the amplitude and duration of an action potential each time it occurs to understand the cell behavior.
explanation: The amplitude and duration are the same for all APs.

text: The neuronal resting membrane potential is given by the sum of diffusional forces, electrical forces, and ion pumps activity

A neuron's firing rate tuning curve reporting the firing rate of a neuron of the primary visual cortex (B) in response to the orientation angle of a visual stimulus (A). If the measured firing rate is 20 Hz, I can infer a univocal orientation angle that produced that response.
explanation: There are two possible orientations that produce a 20 Hz firing rate (-20 and 20 degrees).

text: In reference to the previous figure: from the curve I can conclude that there is a preferred stimulus orientation for which this neuron is designed to respond.
In reference to the previous figure: there are stimulus orientation angles to which this neuron is “blind" (i.e., it doesn't show any response).
A ROC curve describes a threshold classification between two conditions (stimuli) at different levels of coherence of the stimulation. The best curve is the one closer to the upper left corner.
In reference to the previous ROC curve: the Area Under the Curve (AUC) for each level of coherence is proportional to the discriminability of the two conditions.

In reference to the previous ROC curve: by considering only the true positives and false positives, and neglecting the true negatives and false negatives, we miss part of the results of the classification.
explanation: True negatives and false negatives are related to false positives and true positives, respectively. Therefore, we are not neglecting any result of the classification.

text: The difference between the Wiener's and Granger's definitions of causality in the statistical sense is that Granger indicated a modeling framework to be used to test causality.
Given the Granger Index Gxy between two time series x and y, a negative value of Gx→y means an inverse precedence between the two time series.
explanation: A negative value of Gx→y means that the residual of the bivariate model is higher than in the simple model, which is probably due to an incorrect modeling.

text: The Granger Test is more suitable than the Ordinary Coherence to obtain a spectral measure.
explanation: GC is not a spectral measure. OC is.

text: In an undirected graph, I cannot compute the indegree and the outdegree.
explanation: The concept of “in-degree" and "out-degree" is based on directionality.

text: Regular networks have a smaller Local Efficiency than random networks
explanation: Regular networks have a high Local Efficiency (higher than random ones).

text: In a graph, the minimum Divisibility is equal to zero.
explanation: According to the most used normalization, the minimum Divisibility is equal to 0.5. More generally, even with different choices of the term k, D can never be equal to zero.

text: The proper (visual) alpha rhythm is modulated (synchronized, desynchronized) by opening and closing the eyes. This phenomenon is best observed on the frontal EEG channels.
explanation: Only the first half of the statement is true. The primary visual area is located in the occipital cortex, thus the occipital (and parietal) channels are most sensitive.

text: The alpha rhythm can be observed by filtering the spontaneous EEG signal using a narrowband filter, with cutoff frequencies at 14 and 30 Hz (approximately)
explanation: With these cutoff frequencies we would observe the beta rhythm

text: Evoked potential is synonymous of Event-Related Potentials
explanation: Event related potentials include evoke potentials, as well as EEG responses to motor or cognitive events.

text: Despite being more expensive, gold electrodes should be preferred to Ag/AgCl electrodes since they allow recording of extremely slow-changing EEG potentials.
explanation: Gold electrodes are polarizable, thus the opposite is true

text: The CMRR of a bipolar amplifier measures the ratio between the gain of their average with respect to the electrical ground and the gain of the potential difference between the input electrodes.
explanation: Numerator and denominator are swapped

text: The measurement of two monopolar EEG channels requires four electrodes - two collecting the potentials fed to the non-inverting input of the differential amplifier, one providing the reference potential and one providing the ground potential.
explanation: TRUE

text: If the electrodes' contact impedance is not much lower than the amplifier's input impedance, the amplitude of the measured potential is closer to zero than the actual value.
explanation: True. In fact, the series of the electrode impedance and input impedance act as a voltage divider. Only if the former is much lower than the latter, the voltage at the amplifier's input is approximately equal to the actual biological potential.

text: EEG electrodes whose first letter of the label is "C" (e.g. "Cz") are located on the central region of the head, i.e. the region between the left and the right hemisphere
explanation: The central region is above the central sulcus which divides the frontal and parietal lobes. The mesial region is above the interhemispheric scissure, and it is designated by a trailing "z" in EEG labels

text: The artifact generated by eye movements can reach amplitudes up to 5µV in the EEG recordings
explanation: EOG artifacts can be two orders of magnitude higher than that.

text: The heart activity is likely to contaminate an EEG recording if the reference electrode is not placed on the head.
explanation: TRUE

text: In ERP analysis, the EEG continuous recording must be segmented into epochs (trials) of fixed duration, each aligned to a repetition of the event
explanation: TRUE

text: A negative peak in a ERP recorded on a specific subject with a latency of 108ms may still be named N100, if it matches the physiological phenomenon of the nominal N100 component.
explanation: TRUE

text: In an ERP, the response to a stimulus has a reduced amplitude when the SOA is too short.
explanation: TRUE

text: Induced activity is often examined by analyzing the envelope of the EEG in a relevant frequency band, i.e. by rectifying or squaring the pass-band filtered trials before averaging them.
explanation: TRUE

text: The reconstruction of an analog signal from its sampled version is equivalent to the sum a set of sinc() functions, one for each sample.
explanation: TRUE

text: Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled using a limited input range of the ADC.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when an analog signal is sampled outside the conditions set by the Shannon's theorem. Clipping (saturation) occurs when the input range of the ADC is smaller than the amplitude of the input analog signal.

text: In an ADC, quantization introduces a noise whose amplitude is proportional to the width of the quantization interval (VLSB): σquant = 1/√12 VLSB
explanation: TRUE

text: The Average Rectified Value (ARV) is a measure of the amplitude of a signal, and it is obtained by summing the absolute values of all samples and dividing the result by the number of samples.
explanation: TRUE

text: The variance of a signal is estimated by summing the square of all deviations of the N sample values from the sample mean, and then dividing by (N-1)
explanation: TRUE

text: The frequency spectrum of white noise is flat, i.e. it has the same power at any frequency.
explanation: TRUE

text: The Short Time Fourier Transform (STFT) is a simple method to estimate a spectrogram, i.e. the representation of the time-varying spectrum of a non-stationary signal.
explanation: TRUE

text: The roll-off of a filter is the slope of its frequency response in the transition band. It is high when the transition band is narrow.
explanation: TRUE

text: A FIR filter needs to be of a higher order to achieve the same quality specifications than a IIR filter.
explanation: TRUE

text: In a P300-based BCI, the user subjectively assigns saliency (relevance) to a stimulus so that their brain produces a P300 ERP every time the stimulus is administered
explanation: TRUE

text: The proper (visual) alpha rhythm is modulated (synchronized, desynchronized) by opening and closing the eyes. This phenomenon is best observed on the frontal EEG channels.
explanation: Only the first half of the statement is true. The primary visual area is located in the occipital cortex, thus the occipital (and parietal) channels are most sensitive.

text: The alpha rhythm can be observed by filtering the spontaneous EEG signal using a narrowband filter, with cutoff frequencies at 14 and 30 Hz (approximately)
explanation: With these cutoff frequencies we would observe the beta rhythm

text: Evoked potential is synonymous of Event-Related Potentials
explanation: Event related potentials include evoke potentials, as well as EEG responses to motor or cognitive events.

text: Despite being more expensive, gold electrodes should be preferred to Ag/AgCl electrodes since they allow recording of extremely slow-changing EEG potentials.
explanation: Gold electrodes are polarizable, thus the opposite is true

text: The CMRR of a bipolar amplifier measures the ratio between the gain of their average with respect to the electrical ground and the gain of the potential difference between the input electrodes.
explanation: Numerator and denominator are swapped

text: The measurement of two monopolar EEG channels requires four electrodes - two collecting the potentials fed to the non-inverting input of the differential amplifier, one providing the reference potential and one providing the ground potential.
explanation: TRUE

text: If the electrodes' contact impedance is not much lower than the amplifier's input impedance, the amplitude of the measured potential is closer to zero than the actual value.
explanation: True. In fact, the series of the electrode impedance and input impedance act as a voltage divider. Only if the former is much lower than the latter, the voltage at the amplifier's input is approximately equal to the actual biological potential.

text: The proper (visual) alpha rhythm is modulated (synchronized, desynchronized) by opening and closing the eyes. This phenomenon is best observed on the frontal EEG channels.
explanation: Only the first half of the statement is true. The primary visual area is located in the occipital cortex, thus the occipital (and parietal) channels are most sensitive.

text: The powerline noise affects a very narrow frequency band of the recorded signal around 50 Hz (in Europe) and odd multiples of (150 Hz, 250 Hz, ...).
explanation: TRUE

text: Movements of the subject's head produces EEG artifacts mainly in the lowest part of the spectrum.
explanation: Movement of the subject's head may produce slow artifacts on the EEG recording, whose waveform is closely related to the timecourse of the movement

text: When recording EPs, the spontaneous EEG is to be considered a noise that completely masks the EPs on the recorded waveform.
explanation: True. With very rare exceptions (mostly in the field of pathology) EPs are one or more orders of magnitude smaller than the spontaneous EEG.

text: In ERP analysis, 'trials' are portions of the continuous EEG recording that start exactly at the time when a sensory stimulus was delivered
explanation: The start of a trial usually precedes the time of the event, so that a pre-stimulus baseline period can be analyzed. Events are not necessarily sensory stimulations.

text: The N20 component of an EP occurs before the stimulus (negative latency) while the P300 occurs after the stimulus (positive latency).
explanation: 'N' and 'P' indicate the sign of the amplitude of the ERP (Negative and Positive, respectively), not the latency.

text: Event-Related Desynchronization/Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify phase-locked brain activity in response to an event
explanation: Event-Related Desynchronization/Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify relative changes of the power of the EEG rhythm in a predefined frequency range; phase locked activity is estimated using the synchronized averaging.

text: The reconstruction of an analog signal from its sampled version is equivalent to the linear interpolation of the samples.
explanation: The reconstruction of an analog signal from its sampled version is equivalent to the sum a set of sinc() functions, one for each sample.

text: Aliasing occurs when an artifact corrupts an otherwise healthy EEG recording.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when the sampling frequency of an analog signal is lower than twice the frequency of any spectral component of the signal

text: In an ADC, quantization introduces a noise whose amplitude is proportional to the width of the quantization interval (VLSB): σquant = 1/√12 VLSB
explanation: TRUE

text: Potentials recorded by electrodes which are at a close distance on the scalp are mutually independent.
explanation: Due to the volume conduction, there's a strong correlation between scalp potentials recorded at a close spatial distance.

text: A neuron's firing rate tuning curve for movement direction shows the spike trains obtained - for different trials - from a neuron of the primary motor cortex in correspondence to an arm movement (panel A), and the firing rate f of the same neuron as a function of the angle s of the same movement direction (panel B). The maximum neural response is obtained for a movement direction with an angle of 350 degrees.
explanation: The maximum neural response is obtained for a movement direction with an angle of 150 degrees.

text: In reference to the previous figure: from the curve, I can conclude that this neuron is tuned to be more active in correspondence to a specific movement direction.
In reference to the previous figure (question 10): the firing rate f in panel B was computed as the average of the neural response function across trials.

A ROC curve describes a threshold classification between two conditions (stimuli) at different levels of coherence of the stimulation (different curves). The best curve is the one closer to the diagonal.
explanation: The diagonal corresponds to a random binary classification (chance level).

text: In reference to the previous ROC curve: the Area Under the Curve (AUC) for each level of coherence is proportional to the discriminability of the two conditions.

In reference to the previous ROC curve: by considering only the true positives and false positives, and neglecting the true negatives and false negatives, we miss part of the results of the classification.
explanation: True negatives and false negatives are related to false positives and true positives, respectively. Therefore, we are not neglecting any result of the classification.

text: The Spectral Matrix computed for any given pair of time series is always symmetrical.
Given two time series x and y, the Granger Causality Index Gxy ∈[-∞, ∞].
explanation: The Granger Causality Index Gx→y ∈[0,∞].

text: When we have a limited amount of data, the Partial Directed Coherence (PDC) is the most accurate estimator of causality in the statistical sense.
explanation: In the event of data paucity, PDC returns inaccurate results due to the low ratio between data samples and model parameters.

text: The Ordinary Coherence is defined in the time domain.
explanation: It is defined in the spectral domain.

text: A multivariate approach to the estimation of brain networks can always prevent the occurrence of the common source problem.
explanation: Since there is no method able to simultaneously measure all the active sources in the brain, the problem of the common (hidden) source can be mitigated, but not entirely solved, by a multivariate approach.

text: In a graph, when no path links two nodes, the distance between them is infinite.
In a graph, the Density ∈[0, 1].
The Global Efficiency is normalized to the number N of nodes in the graph.
explanation: The Global Efficiency is normalized to the number of edges N(N-1) for directed graphs and N(N-1)/2 for undirected graphs.

explanation: TRUE

text: The Short Time Fourier Transform (STFT) is a simple method to estimate a spectrogram, i.e. the representation of the time-varying spectrum of a non-stationary signal.
explanation: TRUE

explanation: TRUE

text: The contact impedances of a pair of electrodes should be large compared to the input impedance of the differential amplifier connected to them, otherwise the amplitude of the signal would be reduced as effect of the potential divider.
explanation: False, the contact impedances must be lower than the amplifier's input impedance, mainly to help keeping the circuit balanced (higher CMRR)

text: A FIR filter needs to be of a higher order to achieve the same quality specifications than a IIR filter.
explanation: TRUE

text: Event-Related Desynchronization/ Synchronization (ERD/S) quantify the amount of coupling between signals on two EEG channels.
explanation: ERD/S quantify changes of the power of EEG relative to a baseline period

text: ARVx = √(1/N) Σ(x[i])², where the sum extends on the N samples of the signal x[i]
explanation: ARVx = (1/N) Σ|x[i]|, ARV being the acronym of Average Rectified Value

text: Aliasing occurs when an artifact corrupts an otherwise healthy EEG recording.
explanation: Aliasing occurs when the sampling frequency of an analog signal is lower than twice the frequency of any spectral component of the signal

text: Potentials recorded by electrodes which are at a close distance on the scalp are mutually independent.
explanation: Due to the volume conduction, there's a strong correlation between scalp potentials recorded at a close spatial distance.

text: The tuning curve showing the spike trains obtained - for different trials - from a neuron of the primary motor cortex in correspondence to an arm movement (panel A), and the firing rate f of the same neuron as a function of the angle s of the same movement direction (panel B). The maximum neural response is obtained for a movement direction with an angle of 350 degrees.
explanation: The maximum neural response is obtained for a movement direction with an angle of 150 degrees.

text: In reference to the previous figure: from the curve, I can conclude that this neuron is tuned to be more active in correspondence to a specific movement direction.
In reference to the previous figure (question 10): the firing rate f in panel B was computed as the average of the neural response function across trials.

A ROC curve describes a threshold classification between two conditions (stimuli) at different levels of coherence of the stimulation (different curves). The best curve is the one closer to the diagonal.
explanation: The diagonal corresponds to a random binary classification (chance level).

text: In reference to the previous ROC curve: the Area Under the Curve (AUC) for each level of coherence is proportional to the discriminability of the two conditions.

In reference to the previous ROC curve: by considering only the true positives and false positives, and neglecting the true negatives and false negatives, we miss part of the results of the classification.
explanation: True negatives and false negatives are related to false positives and true positives, respectively. Therefore, we are not neglecting any result of the classification.

text: The Spectral Matrix computed for any given pair of time series is always symmetrical.
Given two time series x and y, the Granger Causality Index Gxy ∈[-∞, ∞].
explanation: The Granger Causality Index Gx→y ∈[0,∞].

text: When we have a limited amount of data, the Partial Directed Coherence (PDC) is the most accurate estimator of causality in the statistical sense.
explanation: In the event of data paucity, PDC returns inaccurate results due to the low ratio between data samples and model parameters.

text: The Ordinary Coherence is defined in the time domain.
explanation: It is defined in the spectral domain.

text: A multivariate approach to the estimation of brain networks can always prevent the occurrence of the common source problem.
explanation: Since there is no method able to simultaneously measure all the active sources in the brain, the problem of the common (hidden) source can be mitigated, but not entirely solved, by a multivariate approach.

text: In a graph, when no path links two nodes, the distance between them is infinite.
In a graph, the Density ∈[0, 1].
The Global Efficiency is normalized to the number N of nodes in the graph.
explanation: The Global Efficiency is normalized to the number of edges N(N-1) for directed graphs and N(N-1)/2 for undirected graphs.

text: The powerline noise affects a very narrow frequency band of the recorded signal around 50 Hz (in Europe) and odd multiples of (150 Hz, 250 Hz, ...).
explanation: TRUE

text: The RMS and the ARV of a zero-mean signal have the same value (assume that the number of samples N → ∞).
explanation: For a zero-mean signal, the RMS equals the standard deviation σ of a zero-mean signal.

text: An EEG recording is said to be bipolar when it comprises exactly two channels
explanation: In bipolar EEG recordings, each channel is the difference of potential between two (adjacent) electrodes. The number of channels is not relevant

text: The Shannon's theorem states that a continuous signal can be properly sampled only if it does not contain frequency components above the sampling rate.
explanation: The signal must not contain spectral components above half the sampling rate (Nyquist frequency)

text: Movements of the subject's head produces artifacts only in the gamma band.
explanation: Movement of the subject's head may produce slow artifacts on the EEG recording, whose waveform is closely related to the timecourse of the movement

text: The frequency spectrum of white noise is flat, i.e. it has the same power at any frequency.
explanation: TRUE
